xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: This research received no external funding. The authors like to thank the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) and the European Space Agency (ESA) for the provision of the satellite data. The polarimetric SAR data were acquired under the research proposal 3258 entitled "Evaluating potential applications of polarimetric L-band SAR data over European temperate forests". This study presents the first step towards the analysis of L-band full-polarimetric time series which is already applied on forest issues in ongoing studies. ALOS-PALSAR imagery c JAXA 2017 & 2018. Sentinel-1 imagery c ESA 2017 & 2018. Sentinel-2 imagery c ESA 2017, 2018 & 2019.

affiliation.ce:source-text: Geoinformatics Department, Munich University of Applied Sciences, Karlstraße 6, D-80333 Munich, Germany
German Aerospace Center (DLR), Earth Observation Center (EOC), Oberpfaffenhofen, D-82234Weßling, Germany

organization.$: Institute of Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing (IPF)

affiliation.ce:source-text: Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT), Institute of Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing (IPF), Englerstr. 7, D-76131 Karlsruhe, Germany

head.citation-title: Multi-source and multi-temporal image fusion on hypercomplex bases
head.abstracts: © 2020 by the authors. Licensee MDPI, Basel, Switzerland.This article spanned a new, consistent framework for production, archiving, and provision of analysis ready data (ARD) from multi-source and multi-temporal satellite acquisitions and an subsequent image fusion. The core of the image fusion was an orthogonal transform of the reflectance channels from optical sensors on hypercomplex bases delivered in Kennaugh-like elements, which are well-known from polarimetric radar. In this way, SAR and Optics could be fused to one image data set sharing the characteristics of both: the sharpness of Optics and the texture of SAR. The special properties of Kennaugh elements regarding their scaling-linear, logarithmic, normalized-applied likewise to the newelements and guaranteed their robustness towards noise, radiometric sub-sampling, and therewith data compression. This study combined Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2 on an Octonion basis as well as Sentinel-2 and ALOS-PALSAR-2 on a Sedenion basis. The validation using signatures of typical land cover classes showed that the efficient archiving in 4 bit images still guaranteed an accuracy over 90% in the class assignment. Due to the stability of the resulting class signatures, the fuzziness to be caught by Machine Learning Algorithms was minimized at the same time. Thus, this methodology was predestined to act as new standard for ARD remote sensing data with an subsequent image fusion processed in so-called data cubes.

affiliation.ce:source-text: Geoinformatics Department, Munich University of Applied Sciences, Karlstraße 6, D-80333 Munich, Germany

grant-text.$: This research received no external funding. The authors like to thank the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) and the European Space Agency (ESA) for the provision of the satellite data. The polarimetric SAR data were acquired under the research proposal 3258 entitled "Evaluating potential applications of polarimetric L-band SAR data over European temperate forests". This study presents the first step towards the analysis of L-band full-polarimetric time series which is already applied on forest issues in ongoing studies. ALOS-PALSAR imagery c JAXA 2017 & 2018. Sentinel-1 imagery c ESA 2017 & 2018. Sentinel-2 imagery c ESA 2017, 2018 & 2019.

affiliation.affilname: Deutsches Zentrum für Luft- und Raumfahrt (DLR)

coredata.dc:description: This article spanned a new, consistent framework for production, archiving, and provision of analysis ready data (ARD) from multi-source and multi-temporal satellite acquisitions and an subsequent image fusion. The core of the image fusion was an orthogonal transform of the reflectance channels from optical sensors on hypercomplex bases delivered in Kennaugh-like elements, which are well-known from polarimetric radar. In this way, SAR and Optics could be fused to one image data set sharing the characteristics of both: the sharpness of Optics and the texture of SAR. The special properties of Kennaugh elements regarding their scaling-linear, logarithmic, normalized-applied likewise to the newelements and guaranteed their robustness towards noise, radiometric sub-sampling, and therewith data compression. This study combined Sentinel-1 and Sentinel-2 on an Octonion basis as well as Sentinel-2 and ALOS-PALSAR-2 on a Sedenion basis. The validation using signatures of typical land cover classes showed that the efficient archiving in 4 bit images still guaranteed an accuracy over 90% in the class assignment. Due to the stability of the resulting class signatures, the fuzziness to be caught by Machine Learning Algorithms was minimized at the same time. Thus, this methodology was predestined to act as new standard for ARD remote sensing data with an subsequent image fusion processed in so-called data cubes.
coredata.dc:title: Multi-source and multi-temporal image fusion on hypercomplex bases
